Award.AwardTitle: NUE: A Sustainable Urban Environment Advanced by Engineers Empowered with Nanotechnology

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: The goals of this Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program at Temple University entitled "NUE: A Sustainable Urban Environment Advanced by Engineers Empowered with Nanotechnology", under the direction of Dr. Svetlana Neretina, are two-fold: 1) the broad inclusion of a nanotechnology component within the engineering curiculum and 2)to provide undergraduate engineering students with a hands-on experience directed towards the use of nanotechnogies in advancing a sustainable urban environment. Nanotechnology modules will be added to a minimum of eight courses, exposing every student in the Temple University College of Engineering to nanotechnolgy. A course entitled "Nanotechnology: The Path to a Sustainable Urban Environment" will also become the College's first course dedicated to nanotechnology. Students will gain hands-on experience through research internships, Senior Design Projects and five laboratory teaching modules in the areas of water purification, transportation and renewable energy.

Major Findings - Intellectual Merit:

1. Strength of the Concept: The Temple University NSF NUE theme of advancing a sustainable urban environment through the use of nanotechnology has proved extraordinarily successful in unifying the College of Engineering’s educational and research initiatives in nanotechnology and urban sustainability. The theme of urban sustainability has proved to be timely and of particular importance to urban campuses such as Temple University. The heightened awareness regarding sustainability exhibited by the present generation of undergraduate students has been particularly effective in attracting high quality undergraduate students to this nanotechnology initiative. Having made this initiative College-wide and encompassing a wide array of topics (renewable and alternative energy solutions, water purification and wastewater treatment, human health and transportation), the overall significance of nanotechnology has been amplified.

 2. Hands-on-Training in Nanotechnology: One of the main goals of the NSF NUE award was to give undergraduate engineering students hands-on training with nanomaterials and the instrumentation used to characterize them. With seven summer research internships in 2011 and six in 2012 these experiences were crucial to the success of the program. In addition, the laboratory teaching modules which have been developed and introduced into existing course offerings have proved quite popular among undergraduate students.

 3. Benefits to Teaching: Faculty members participating in the NSF NUE have offered a strong endorsement of the program. The fact that five faculty members, who were not originally part of the NUE initiative, have now joined provides a strong indication that the incorporation of a nanotechnology component into the engineering curriculum is on track and gaining momentum.

 4. Benefits to Research: The number of faculty members who were interested in supervising a summer research internship far exceeded the internships available. With one undergraduate participant receiving a Diamond Scholarship, partially as a result of her NUE-sponsored research experience during the spring semester, we were able to increase the total number of summer-internship projects to 13. Thus far, this research has resulted in the submission of three manuscripts to peer-reviewed journals (one accepted), three conference proceedings and five conference presentations.

Major Findings – Broader Impact:

 1. Impact on Student Awareness: Uniting the College of Engineering’s research programs in nanotechnology all under the umbrella of urban sustainability has increased overall student awareness of nanotechnology. All significant College events (open houses, National Engineers Week, research poster presentations) now have both student and faculty participation from the NUE program. Surprisingly, student awareness and interest were raised substantially by the video advertisement requesting applications for the summer internships in nanotechnology which were viewed by all students on a video monitor as they entered the College of Engineering. This combined with a steadily increasing number of course offerings which include a nanotechnology module provides the constant exposure needed to significantly impact student awareness.

 2. Impact on K-12 Education: In July of 2010, a nanotechnology activity was added to the Women’s Engineering Exploration for High School Students Program.
